|Title=Know how to prescribe emergency samples prior to antibiotic therapy
|Description=Know how to prescribe blood cultures prior to emergency antibiotic therapy
|Section=Additional tests
|Contributors=David Lebeaux
|Order=8}}
Microbiological tests must be taken before the start of antibiotic therapy (including the [[Positive blood culture SD-190|haemocultures]], see below).

The exceptions to this rule are :

- Purpura fulminans

- Patients presenting with septic shock or bacterial meningitis whose microbiological sampling would delay the start of antibiotic therapy by more than one hour.

question.question: When should microbiological tests, such as blood cultures, be taken in relation to the start of antibiotic therapy?
question.option_a: Microbiological tests should be taken after the start of antibiotic therapy to avoid contamination.
question.option_b: Microbiological tests should be taken before the start of antibiotic therapy, except in cases of purpura fulminans or when sampling would delay antibiotic therapy by more than one hour.
question.option_c: Microbiological tests should always be taken simultaneously with the start of antibiotic therapy to ensure accurate results.
question.option_d: Microbiological tests are not necessary if the patient is already showing signs of improvement with antibiotic therapy.
